Description: Canopy school ID number assigned by the Canopy project
Name of the school

State where the school is located
School district
Indicates whether the entity represented by the NCES ID is a larger entity than the school represented by Canopy data.
Number of years the current school leader has been in their position at the school
Survey respondent's answer to the question "Are you interested in partnering with researchers to answer key questions about your schoolâ€™s model?"
Survey respondent's answer to the question "How do you measure the success of your school model?"
Survey respondent evaluation of how well the tags allowed them to describe the school's model (Very Well, Well, Not Very Well, Poorly)
Survey respondent's suggestions for additional keywords that could be used to describe the school (beyond selected tags)

Survey respondent 's answer to the question "The Canopy project focuses on documenting the practices that innovative schools are implementing at a schoolwide level, but many schools are experimenting with smaller-scale innovations this year - for example, within specific grade levels or classrooms.  Would you like to highlight any promising practices that have emerged in your school so far this year, but are not part of your whole-school model?"

Students learn both online and in-person, in which both learning environments are connected to provide an integrated learning experience, and with some element of student control over the time, place, path, or pace of learning.

The school's model is designed to ensure students are becoming proficient by advancing on demonstrated mastery. May include a deliberate focus on student agency, transparent learning expectations, timely/differentiated supports, varied pacing and pathways, meaningful and formative assessment.
Notes: A value of "1" indicates that the survey respondent reported the practice at the school. A value showing a time period indicates that the survey respondent both reported the practice, and indicated it as one of up to five practices that are core to the school model. The time period refers to the length of time the survey respondent reports the core practice being implemented.

A value showing a time period indicates that the survey respondent both reported the practice, and indicated it as one of up to five practices that are core to the school model. The time period refers to the length of time the survey respondent reports the core practice being implemented.

Description: The school creates deliberate structures and processes for peer support, e.g. peer mentorship, peer tutoring, accountability partners, etc.
Notes: A value of "1" indicates that the survey respondent reported the practice at the school. A value showing a time period indicates that the survey respondent both reported the practice, and indicated it as one of up to five practices that are core to the school model. The time period refers to the length of time the survey respondent reports the core practice being implemented.

Description: Students rotate through stations on a fixed schedule, where at least one of the stations is an online learning station.
Notes: A value of "1" indicates that the survey respondent reported the practice at the school. Description: Grades are reported on a standards-based report card, and focus on the specific competencies students are expected to develop.

Description: Students have more than one opportunity to demonstrate their learning in order to show they have achieved mastery.

Description: Online learning activities occur synchronously, where consistent groups of students participate at the same designated time.

Description: For remote learning, curricular materials are printed and distributed physically.
Notes: A value of "1" indicates that the survey respondent reported the practice at the school. Description: Students plan and lead a meeting including parents and teachers to discuss the student's learning and growth. (As opposed to parent-teacher conferences without students present.)
Notes: A value of "1" indicates that the survey respondent reported the practice at the school. A value showing a time period indicates that the survey respondent both reported the practice, and indicated it as one of up to five practices that are core to the school model. The time period refers to the length of time the survey respondent reports the core practice being implemented.

Description: The school involves families in shared decision-making, and communicates how family input has informed decision-making. This may include strategies such as participatory budgeting, family advisory groups, etc.
Notes: A value of "1" indicates that the survey respondent reported the practice at the school. A value showing a time period indicates that the survey respondent both reported the practice, and indicated it as one of up to five practices that are core to the school model. The time period refers to the length of time the survey respondent reports the core practice being implemented.

Description: Students engage in design thinking, a structured framework for identifying challenges, gathering information, generating potential solutions, refining ideas, and testing solutions.
Notes: A value of "1" indicates that the survey respondent reported the practice at the school. A value showing a time period indicates that the survey respondent both reported the practice, and indicated it as one of up to five practices that are core to the school model. Description: Design maximizes for flexibility and student choice, e.g. multi-purpose spaces, moveable walls, furniture can be arranged in different configurations, etc.

Description: The school designs learning experiences to proactively meet the needs of all learners by identifying barriers to learning in the design of the environment, not in the student. Description: Desire to be on the cutting edge and demonstrate what's possible.

School-wide Title I indicator. A program in which all the pupils in a school are designated under appropriate state and federal regulations as being eligible for participation in programs authorized by Title I of Public Law 103-382.
Indicates if a school is a Charter, District (traditional public school), or Independant (private)

Indicates whether the school is a magnet school. A magnet is a special school or program designed to attract students of different racial/ethnic backgrounds for the purpose of reducing, preventing, or eliminating racial isolation (50 percent or more minority enrollment); and/or to provide an academic or social focus on a particular theme (e.g., science/mathematics, performing arts, gifted/talented, or foreign language).
The unduplicated count of students in membership whose National School Lunch Program (NSLP) eligibility has been determined through direct certification
School's website

Indicates whether the school is located in an urban, suburban, or rural context. This variable was determined by the Christensen Institute based on the local_original variable. "City" codes were categorized as Urban, "Suburb" codes were categorized as Suburban, and "Rural" and "Town" codes were categorized as rural.
Percentage of students eligible to participate in the Free and Reduced-Price Lunch Program
